item.title: Spokesman for South Korean Leader Quits
item.description: Reports that the spokesman for President Park Geun-hye of South Korea groped a woman in Washington were followed by his abrupt departure.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 3 Ultra-Orthodox Men Arrested at Western Wall
item.description: Thousands joined protest against ruling that banned gender segregation at the Jerusalem holy site.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A police officer tried to stop an Ultra-Orthodox man from interfering with the group known as Women of the Wall during its monthly prayer at the Western Wall on Friday in Jerusalem.

item.title: British Police Deny Protecting Jimmy Savile
item.description: A report by the West Yorkshire police covered 68 of hundreds of sexual abuse allegations that have surfaced against the former television presenter Jimmy Savile.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: India Ranks Number One in Cervical Cancer Deaths
item.description: Of the 50 countries surveyed, maximum deaths from cervical cancer occurred in India, a new report says.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Anandibai Kedari, a cervical cancer patient, right, with Sister Flavia at the CIPLA Palliative Care and Training Center in Pune, Maharashtra, on May 28, 2007.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 10
item.description: Syria’s young bearing brunt of war; an effort to bring the Roma into Slovakian mainstream; a lawsuit against the Bank of Spain; and a duel between new major museums in China.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrian refugees at the Zaatari refugee camp collected bread at a distribution center administered by the World Food Program.

item.title: Woman Is Arrested in Rape Rumor That Ignited Beijing Protest
item.description: Rumors that a woman who died had been the victim of a rape led hundreds of workers to protest in the streets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: What’s Wrong With the C.B.I.? Former Directors Weigh In
item.description: Can India’s top investigative agency function independently from government?
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Bangladesh Collapse Death Toll Passes 1,000
item.description: Workers have found many more bodies as they have used machinery to remove the most heavily damaged sections of a building that collapsed.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Sailor Dies in America’s Cup Training as Yacht Capsizes
item.description: Andrew Simpson, a British sailor and Olympic gold medalist, was caught beneath the capsized boat, the team said. Simpson had been sailing for Artemis, Sweden’s entry in the America’s Cup.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: A 72-foot America’s Cup yacht owned by the Swedish team Artemis Racing capsized during training in San Francisco Bay on Thursday.

item.title: Tunisian Is Charged With Seeking to Build a Terrorist Network in the U.S.
item.description: Ahmed Abassi is also accused of seeking to develop a terrorist network in the United States, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
item.description: The intensity of a fight between House Republicans and the Obama administration came down to a single word.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, then the secretary of state, testified in January about the assault on the diplomatic mission in Libya.

item.title: Efraín Ríos Montt Denies Role in Guatemalan Massacres
item.description: In a rambling statement on Thursday lasting almost an hour, Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt said he had never authorized or proposed attacks on any ethnic groups.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Indigenous women attended the genocide trial of Gen. Efraín Ríos Montt, the former dictator of Guatemala, on Thursday.

item.title: Islamist Leader in Bangladesh Gets Death Sentence for War Atrocities
item.description: An Islamist party leader was convicted of the genocide of unarmed civilians during the 1971 war to break away from Pakistan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: In Slovakia, Integration of Roma Mirrors Early Struggles in U.S
item.description: Eastern Slovakia’s elementary schools are a microcosm of one of Europe’s biggest challenges: how to bring its most disadvantaged minority into the mainstream.
item.category: Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Tomasz Lazar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A court ruling is slowly helping lead to joint classes for white and Roma students in Slovakia.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Those Aiding Iran
item.description: The actions appeared to signal an accelerated American effort to squeeze Iran economically over the lack of progress in negotiations on its disputed nuclear program.
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Russia, Marathon Bombing Suspect Talked Jihad
item.description: Acquaintances of Tamerlan Tsarnaev in Russia said he was already interested in waging jihad when he arrived there last year, but they discouraged him from joining a militant group.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: For International Students, College Checklists for May
item.description: College counselors in the United States offer monthly advice for juniors and seniors who want to stay on track during the admissions process.
item.dc:creator: By RICK HAZELTON and J.T. DUCK

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: Report Tallies Repression
item.description: Eritrea’s government has jailed about 10,000 dissidents without charge or trial over the years, Amnesty International reported Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Thousands of Peacekeepers Have Died During Mission, U.N. Says
item.description: As many as 3,000 African Union peacekeepers have been killed in Somalia in recent years trying to bring stability, the United Nations deputy secretary general said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Uruguay: General Is Convicted
item.description: Uruguay has convicted Gen. Miguel Dalmao of human rights violations during the country’s dictatorship.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Detained American Is Allowed Visitors
item.description: Venezuela has permitted American diplomats to meet with Timothy Tracy, a California filmmaker awaiting trial on charges of espionage and fomenting unrest.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: CULIACÁN Journal: Mexican City Tries to Reshape Its Violent Image
item.description: Memorials to victims of drug violence are ubiquitous in Culiacán, but officials are slowly asking families’ permission to replace them with discreet marble plaques.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cenotaph across the street from the university in Culiacán. Many people here believe that the soul lingers forever in the last spot where it was alive.

item.title: Hezbollah Threatens Israel Over Syria Strikes
item.description: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, suggested Syria would retaliate by providing his fighters with weapons that Israel wanted to keep out of the group’s hands.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader, said his group would get “unique weapons” from Syria.

item.title: Uproar in Germany Over Nazi Scenes in Wagner’s ‘Tannhäuser’
item.description: The reaction to the new production of “Tannhäuser” in Düsseldorf on opening night led management to announce it would now be performed as a concert, with little in the way of staging or costumes.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Hans Joerg Michel/Deutsche Oper am Rhein, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A scene from a new production of Richard Wagner’s opera, Tannhäuser in Düsseldorf.

item.title: German Finance Minister Puts Focus on Unemployment
item.description: At an investment conference in London, Wolfgang Schäuble cited joblessness among young people as Europe’s biggest problem.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
